title: What Happens When You Give Teenagers the Keys to Your Museum?
content:
Here’s a thought experiment: What if your museum handed over its TikTok account to a bunch of teenagers—no filters, no approvals, just… full access?

If your heart just skipped a beat, you’re not alone.

Most cultural institutions would call that a PR risk. But at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, it’s business as usual. In fact, it’s part of a radical (and remarkably successful) strategy for youth engagement that’s been quietly reshaping the museum from the inside out.

title: Stress-Free Museum Visits? How ‘Quiet Hours’ Are Changing the Game
content:
Museums have long been sanctuaries of art, history, and culture, offering visitors a chance to step away from the hustle and bustle of daily life. But for some people, traditional museum visits can feel overwhelming—the crowds, bright lights, and background noise can turn what should be a calming experience into a stressful one.

To address this, many museums are introducing ‘Quiet Hours’ or ‘Quiet Visits.’ These dedicated periods provide a calmer, more sensory-friendly environment, making museums more inclusive and welcoming.

What Are ‘Quiet Hours’ in Museums?

content:

title: How to Create a Viral Video for a Museum
content:
What does it really take to create a viral video for a museum? Is it about the object on screen, the quick editing, the platform, or the storytelling? To uncover the reality behind museum social media success, we asked social media experts at London Museum, Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam, and The National Gallery to share the strategies that have helped their videos reach millions.

Their insights reveal that viral museum videos are not accidents. They are crafted through authenticity, curiosity, and the courage to show museums as human, creative places. title: English Heritage’s Shout Out Loud: Supporting Creative Skills for Young People
content:
If you ask most people what heritage organisations do, they will probably point you toward the past, stories carved in stone, artefacts under glass, timelines printed on crisp exhibition panels. title: Inside V&A East Storehouse, A Radical Rethink of What a Museum Can Be
content:
Walk into the V&A East Storehouse and the first thing that hits you is the scale. Half a million objects sit in a vast former Olympic press building, from eighteenth century paintings to netsuke small enough to balance on a fingertip. Decades of curatorial care are visible everywhere. Lacquer sits in climate controlled cabinets, textiles stretch across rolling racks, and fragile objects sleep in precisely engineered housings.

title: Designing for the Planet: Lessons on Sustainable Exhibition Design
content:
Sustainable exhibition design is no longer an optional enhancement, it is an expectation shared by audiences, funders, and cultural workers who increasingly recognise museums as civic actors in the climate crisis. As the sector experiments with new materials, new workflows, and new value systems, pioneering organisations are showing what sustainable practice looks like in action.

Drawing on presentations from Documenta, Miraikan and Young V&A at the Green Museums Summit, this article distils the key lessons emerging from real-world projects that are redefining how exhibitions are conceived, built and maintained for a post-carbon future.

content:
